pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.2: a certain brahmin had invited the nuns for a meal.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.3: When the nuns had finished and refused an invitation to eat more, they went to their respective families, where some ate and others got almsfood and left.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.4: Soon afterwards that brahmin said this to his neighbors,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.5: “I have satisfied the nuns. Come, and I’ll satisfy you, too.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.8: Those nuns who were invited by you came to our houses, where some ate and others got almsfood and left.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.9: That brahmin complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.10: “How could they eat in our house and afterwards eat elsewhere? Am I not able to give them as much as they want?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.11: The nuns heard the complaints of that brahmin,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.12: and the nuns of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.13: “How could nuns finish their meal, refuse an invitation to eat more, and then eat elsewhere?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.14: “Is it true, monks, that nuns did this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.17: “How could nuns act in this way?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.19: “And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule like this:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:1.20.1: ‘If a nun, who has been invited to a meal, refuses an invitation to eat more, and then eats fresh or cooked food, she commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.1.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination in unanimity by both Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.1.5: Refuses an offer to eat more:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.1.6: refuses an offer to eat any of the five cooked foods.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.1.7: Refuses an invitation to eat more:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.1.8: eating is seen, cooked food is seen, it is brought forward within arm’s reach, a refusal is seen.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.1.10: apart from the five cooked foods, congee, the post-midday tonics, the seven-day tonics, and the lifetime tonics,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.1.13: there are five kinds of cooked food: cooked grain, porridge, flour products, fish, and meat.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.1.14: If she receives it with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.1.15: For every mouthful, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.2.1: If she has refused an offer, and she perceives that she has, and she eats fresh or cooked food, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.2.2: If she has refused an offer, but she is unsure of it, and she eats fresh or cooked food, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.2.3: If she has refused an offer, but she does not perceive that she has, and she eats fresh or cooked food, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.2.4: If she receives post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics for the purpose of food, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.2.5: For every mouthful, she commits an offense of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.2.7: if she has refused an offer to eat more, but not an invitation;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.2.9: if she eats more after getting permission from the person who invited her;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.2.10: if, when there is a reason, she uses post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.2.12: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54:2.2.13: The fourth training rule is finished.
